content:
ContainerVisual Class

Definition

Manages a collection of Visual objects.

In this Article

public class ContainerVisual : System.Windows.Media.Visual
Inheritance
Object
DispatcherObject
DependencyObject
System.Windows.Media.Visual
ContainerVisual

Remarks

The ContainerVisual class is used as a container for a collection of Visual objects. The DrawingVisual class derives from the ContainerVisual class, such that the DrawingVisual class can also contain a collection of visual objects.

Constructors

ContainerVisual()

Creates a new instance of the ContainerVisual class.

public ContainerVisual ();

Properties

BitmapEffect

Gets or sets a BitmapEffect value for the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.Effects.BitmapEffect BitmapEffect { get; set; }
Value
BitmapEffect

The bitmap effect for this visual object.

BitmapEffectInput

Gets or sets a BitmapEffectInput value for the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.Effects.BitmapEffectInput BitmapEffectInput { get; set; }
Value
BitmapEffectInput

The bitmap effect input value for this visual object.

CacheMode

Gets or sets a cached representation of the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.CacheMode CacheMode { get; set; }
Value
CacheMode

A CacheMode that holds a cached representation of the ContainerVisual.

Remarks

Set the CacheMode property when you need to increase performance for content that is time-consuming to render. For more information, see BitmapCache.

Children

Gets the child collection of the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.VisualCollection Children { get; }
Value
VisualCollection

A VisualCollection that contains the children of the ContainerVisual.

Clip

Gets or sets the clipping region of the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.Geometry Clip { get; set; }
Value
Geometry

The Geometry that defines the clipping region.

ContentBounds

Gets the bounding box for the contents of the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Rect ContentBounds { get; }
Value
Rect

A Rect that specifies the bounding box.

Remarks

Use the DescendantBounds property to return the union of all the content bounding boxes for all of the descendants of a ContainerVisual object, but not the object itself.

DescendantBounds

Gets the union of all the content bounding boxes for all of the descendants of the ContainerVisual, but not including the contents of the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Rect DescendantBounds { get; }
Value
Rect

A Rect that specifies the combination bounding box.

Remarks

Get the ContentBounds property to return the cached bounding box rectangle for the ContainerVisual itself.

Effect

Gets or sets the bitmap effect to apply to the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.Effects.Effect Effect { get; set; }
Value
Effect

An Effect that represents the bitmap effect.

Offset

Gets or sets the offset value of the ContainerVisual from its reference point.

public System.Windows.Vector Offset { get; set; }
Value
Vector

A Vector that represents the offset value of the ContainerVisual.

Opacity

Gets or sets the opacity of the ContainerVisual, based on 0=transparent, 1=opaque.

public double Opacity { get; set; }
Value
Double

A value from 0 through 1 that specifies a range from fully transparent to fully opaque. A value of 0 indicates that the ContainerVisual is completely transparent, while a value of 1 indicates that the ContainerVisual is completely opaque. A value 0.5 indicates 50 percent opaque, a value of 0.725 indicates 72.5 percent opaque, and so on. Values less than 0 are treated as 0, while values greater than 1 are treated as 1.

OpacityMask

Gets or sets a brush that specifies a possible opacity mask for the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.Brush OpacityMask { get; set; }
Value
Brush

A value of type Brush that represents the opacity mask value of the ContainerVisual.

Remarks

Opacity masks can be used to create effects such as vignettes, based on the alpha channel values of the brush.

Parent

Gets the parent Visual for the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.DependencyObject Parent { get; }
Value
DependencyObject

The parent of the visual.

Remarks

Note that this is returned as DependencyObject, rather than a raw object.

This property might return null in a disconnected tree, or if you have traversed to the tree root at the window level.

Transform

Gets or sets the transform that is applied to the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.Transform Transform { get; set; }
Value
Transform

The transform value.

Remarks

Transform is a base class that unifies many different forms of transforms. For details, see Transform.

VisualChildrenCount

Gets the number of children for the ContainerVisual.

protected override sealed int VisualChildrenCount { get; }
Value
Int32

The number of children in the VisualCollection of the ContainerVisual.

Remarks

By default, a ContainerVisual does not have any children.

XSnappingGuidelines

Gets or sets the X (horizontal) guideline for the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.DoubleCollection XSnappingGuidelines { get; set; }
Value
DoubleCollection

The horizontal guideline.

Remarks

Pixel snapping is the process in which content layout is fixed so that object edges are rendered on device-specific pixels. The WPF graphics system uses device-independent units to enable resolution and device independence. Each device independent pixel automatically scales with the system's dots per inch (dpi) setting. This provides WPF applications proper scaling for different dpi settings and makes the application automatically dpi-aware.

However, this dpi independence can create irregular edge rendering due to anti-aliasing. These artifacts, commonly seen as blurry, or "soft" edges, can occur when the location of an edge falls in the middle of a device pixel rather than between device pixels. To address this issue, WPF provides a way for object edges in a visual tree to "snap" to device pixels through pixel snapping, eliminating the soft edges produced by anti-aliasing.

YSnappingGuidelines

Gets or sets the Y (vertical) guideline for the ContainerVisual.

public System.Windows.Media.DoubleCollection YSnappingGuidelines { get; set; }
Value
DoubleCollection

The vertical guideline.

Remarks

Pixel snapping is the process in which content layout is fixed so that object edges are rendered on device-specific pixels. The WPF graphics system uses device-independent units to enable resolution and device independence. Each device independent pixel automatically scales with the system's dots per inch (dpi) setting. This provides WPF applications proper scaling for different dpi settings and makes the application automatically dpi-aware.

However, this dpi independence can create irregular edge rendering due to anti-aliasing. These artifacts, commonly seen as blurry, or "soft" edges, can occur when the location of an edge falls in the middle of a device pixel rather than between device pixels. To address this issue, WPF provides a way for object edges in a visual tree to "snap" to device pixels through pixel snapping, eliminating the soft edges produced by anti-aliasing.

Methods

GetVisualChild(Int32)

Returns a specified child Visual for the parent ContainerVisual.

protected override sealed System.Windows.Media.Visual GetVisualChild (int index);
index
Int32

A 32-bit signed integer that represents the index value of the child Visual. The value of index must be between 0 and stem.Windows.Media.ContainerVisual.VisualChildrenCount* - 1.

Returns
System.Windows.Media.Visual

The child Visual.

Remarks

By default, a ContainerVisual does not have any children.

HitTest(Point)

Returns the top-most visual object of a hit test by specifying a Point.

public System.Windows.Media.HitTestResult HitTest (System.Windows.Point point);
point
Point

The point value to hit test.

Returns
HitTestResult

The hit test result of the visual returned as a HitTestResult type.

Remarks

The VisualHit property of the return value represents the Visual object that was hit.

HitTest(HitTestFilterCallback,HitTestResultCallback,HitTestParameters)

Initiates a hit test on the ContainerVisual by using the HitTestFilterCallback and HitTestResultCallback objects.

public void HitTest (System.Windows.Media.HitTestFilterCallback filterCallback, System.Windows.Media.HitTestResultCallback resultCallback, System.Windows.Media.HitTestParameters hitTestParameters);
filterCallback
HitTestFilterCallback

The delegate that allows you to ignore parts of the visual tree that you are not interested in processing in your hit test results.

resultCallback
HitTestResultCallback

The delegate that is used to control the return of hit test information.

hitTestParameters
HitTestParameters

Defines the set of parameters for a hit test.

Remarks

The filterCallback parameter can be null, in which case, it is ignored. If filterCallback is not null, it is invoked before resultCallback.
